qas.question: What is the common name for shapes and forms of bacteria?
Are bacteria cells smaller than eukaryotic cells?
What are one of the smallest bacteria?

context: Bacteria display a wide diversity of shapes and sizes, called <a0_0>morphologies<a0_0/>. Bacterial cells are about <a1_0>one-tenth the size<a1_0/> of eukaryotic cells and are typically 0.5–5.0 micrometres in length. However, a few species are visible to the unaided eye — for example, Thiomargarita namibiensis is up to half a millimetre long and Epulopiscium fishelsoni reaches <a2_0>0.7 mm<a2_0/>. Among the smallest bacteria are members of the <a3_0>genus Mycoplasma<a3_0/>, which measure only 0.3 micrometres, as small as the largest viruses. Some bacteria may be even smaller, but these ultramicrobacteria are <a4_0>not well-studied<a4_0/>.
